What is a Brand?


What is a brand? What does "branding" mean? Why does it matter?
These are all questions you might ask while creating a visual communication piece. Specifically you might ask, "Does my little flyer really matter"? The answer is that your piece, no matter how large or small, matters and is a part of the overall BYU-Idaho brand. Let's see why.

Brands are built over time

BYU-Idaho's visual identity has been evolving since the school was founded. In our Ricks College days, images such as the Viking ship, the mighty oak, the Teton peak and the Viking warrior were all recognized icons and symbolic to the development of the college.



As BYU-Idaho continues to evolve the importance of brand identity has increased, and there is a growing need for more consistency and greater quality and coordination in visual and written communication.


Using a logo

A key element of an organization's brand is the consistent use of a logo. When people see an established logo, they envision that organization-its products and services, what it represents and what it promotes.



Like all reputable organizations, BYU-Idaho has an official, identifiable logo.



Now more than ever, a consistent and clear brand identity is crucial to the communication of our message. Our logo and other visual identifiers need to be clean, scholarly and dignified. By increasing our level of adherence to the BYU-Idaho brand identity standards, we are able to continue to project the mission and spirit of our organization in a professional way.


Brands include color and type

Brands are not just built upon a logo alone. Specific colors and typefaces can also be associated with a brand over time. For example, do you know what organizations are linked to these colors?




Can you identify these companies simply by the type?




Like many of these companies, BYU-Idaho also has a color palette and a limited set of typefaces that represent the university, and it is important to use these when creating official communication pieces.






Brands include Imagery

Most communication pieces include images which help add visual appeal and also become part of an overall brand. BYU-Idaho imagery features students and should exemplify Student Honor and the appropriate dress and grooming standards.




Even presenting information such as charts and graphs become part of the brand. When producing these graphics design should not draw negative attention to itself by being ornate or overly busy. Clear communication and a scholarly, dignified presentation should always be the goal.




Brands incorporate appropriate terminology

A brand also includes terminology and language. BYU-Idaho has established naming conventions for buildings, departments, offices and programs. Consistent use of these guides will ensure that information is presented accurately while conveying the appropriate tone and feel of the university.


Brands communicate

The tools of branding are used internally with students and employees. They are also implemented externally among the community, prospective students, alumni and the world at large. As people experience positive communication from BYU-Idaho, a favorable opinion of the university is formed. This opinion of the university is our brand. We build and influence this brand one impression at a time.


Conclusion

Building a brand is about the future. Building a brand requires the cooperation and participation of every member of the BYU-Idaho community. "Does my little flyer really matter?" Hopefully you can see that it does. Over time, with consistent application of established standards, we can all develop a strong brand that represents the core values and mission of our great university.
